mn61:1.1: This Buddha teaches his son Rāhula of the dangers of lying, using gestures to illustrate his point. The simple subject matter and child-friendly methods support the commentary’s claim that this was soon after Rāhula ordained ([pli-tv-kd1:54.1.1]()), when he was still a boy. This sutta is among those recommended for study by the Saṅgha by King Ashoka in Minor Rock Edict No. 3, the Calcutta-Bairāṭ rock inscription from Viratnagar in Rajasthan. There it is described as “the exhortation to Rāhula spoken by the blessed Buddha concerning falsehood” (_laghulo-vāde musā-vādaṃ adhigicya bhagavatā budhena bhāsite_).
mn61:2.1: The commentary says this is a building next to the Bamboo Grove rather than the site of the royal rest-house mentioned at [dn1:1.2.1](). However, to get there from the Bamboo Grove was only an hour or so’s walk, so I think it’s more likely to be the same place.
